history.content:
While I understand you might not have enjoyed 61B as a class, there's a big gap between the programming in 61B and the programming you do in an SDE internship; I'd encourage you to apply for one, simply because the experience as an intern is a much better guide in terms of career path than anything else you can do inside your classes. As an intern, you'll learn a lot more about the SDE culture, how software development works in industry, and will get a much wider exposure to the kinds of problems you work on as an SDE (as opposed to in class projects) - even if you decide not to be an SDE later, that experience is very valuable, so I would encourage you to try for one. 

You could also look into Data Science as a potential field, which might be more oriented to your skillset than pure software engineering.

Hi I am a rising junior CS major. Throughout my lower div CS courses I have found to not really enjoy programming as a career (i didnt really like 61B but I really enjoyed 70) and am averse to pursuing software engineer internships or roles as a result. However, I love theory and applications such as machine learning and optimization as well as applying my computer science and tech field knowledge to finance and other fields. Does anyone have any suggestions as to what kind of internships I should be looking for this upcoming summer so i could have a better sense of what I should do with my life based on my interests so far? Any suggestions would be appreciated. Thanks!

(I have not had any previous internship thus far. In my freshman summer, I took CS 70 and did like biotech research. This summer, I am doing research in the eecs department)

P.S: I did look at the previous post about swe research but I am not sure if that would be interesting to me either as it seems I need a PhD (which I don't want to pursue as of now) to have any meaningful impact. I also tried looking into PM internships but those seemed impossible to get unless I had a perfect gpa or something. Also my resume is trash as I not only have a mediocre gpa as of now but also have no tech internships.

P.S: I also did look into being a quant but that seemed to be too hellish from my friends' experiences.
history.subject: Career advice for someone who does not want to do swe
